If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.

Steps to reproduce
------------------
Enter `python` in PowerShell
Enter some code: `print("Hello, world!")`
Press Ctrl + L

Expected behavior
-----------------
Screen clears to `>>>` (or scrolls up so the previous shell input and output can no longer be seen)


Actual behavior
---------------
`^L` prints to the console

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
Hum! I don't think is PowerShell but the Windows version of Python.  Please include the version of Python. 

The actual behavior in Ubuntu using Ctrl-L is to move the code up and it looks like it cleared the screen but it didn't.  As, you can scroll-Up and see the code again.

By the way, the same error happens when you execute Python from the DOS command prompt.

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
Found out to clear the whole Python code during the session could use the following:

import os
var=os.system("tput reset")

I know is not pretty but it works. The purpose of the variable var is to hide the "0" result value.

Below is the reference link: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27420880/how-to-clear-python-console-i-e-ctrll-command-line-equivalent
:)

comments.author: BrucePay
comments.body: There is no magic processing going on here. ctrl-L is the ASCII form-feed character. Sending that character to a terminal causes it to jump one screen forward. The Windows console subsystem is not a terminal and doesn't respond to ctrl-L. I'm closing this as resolution-external since the console would have to be enhanced to understand ctrl-L.

title: Ctrl + L in Python inside Powershell fails to clear the screen
